posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18798697
Sourdough refers to using natural yeast from the air for rising, rather than dried/fresh store bought stuff. Not sure where the salt comes into it other than stopping the yeast going out of control.
I assume any oven type is useable aslong as it gets hot enough. I bake at 220c for 30-40 minutes for a full sized (800g~) loaf.
If you over proof dough before baking the structure will collapse in the oven and youll get a flat loaf.

It's not an ethical reaction, he doesn't see eating meat as morally wrong, it's that after not eating meat for a year or so his body doesn't want it anymore so it doesn't seem appetizing at all. The exact same way that some who focus on meat find things like salads or broccoli disgusting.

What you think you enjoy, what you crave and even how you think is heavily, heavily influenced by the bacteria in your gut that digest the food you eat. If you think of yourself as a collection of human cells, then you yourself don't digest anything at all. You have a bag of tissue filled with a whole bunch of bacteria that like to eat different things and they send signals to your brain telling you what you think you want based on what the majority of the bacteria there like to eat.

That's why I go to alcoholism as a good example because it's so extreme. Once the gut becomes saturated with bacteria craving alcohol over real food, many get seriously fucked. It's feasible for the body to focus on only eating meat or only eating vegetables and be mostly fine, but if it switches to mainly alcohol all the regular syste break down. Yet you see this all over.

Ate at a Persian restaurant: Skewer of chicken (it was excellent, tender, succulent, juicy, everything you want out of chicken), a little parsley salad, saffron rice, a wedge of roast potato, tzatziki sauce and hot sauce on the side and a piece of pita bread, drank water.

>>18804771
the key to getting into salads is to eat seasonally so that you enjoy produce at its best.
in spring i do snow peas, romaine, goat cheese, and sometimes mint with a basic lemon dressing
for summer: sliced nectarines, spinach, basil, feta, black pepper, and balsamic vinegar
in autumn, a cabbage slaw with ginger dressing makes a great side
for winter, i like to make use of citrus. walnuts (candied, sometimes), fennel, and orange work great together

cheese, citrus, and pickled red onions (yes i know those are overdone) give life to salads. nuts, seeds, and healthier grains like farro and wheat berries add protein and will keep you fuller for longer. don't punish yourself by eating pure greens.

in addition to this, try to take a walk most days a week either in the morning or evening. once you start eating better and moving more, you'll feel better overall

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18804771
There's a /fat/ thread on /fit/. The thing you have to be careful with salads are dressings as long as they're actual salads, if you start adding croutons, bacon, cheese... then you're eating deconstructed pizza. What works for me is eating the same meal multiple times through the week what I have are very simple salads with lettuce and tomatoes, olive oil, vinegar and salt and you can be really generous with the amounts. Then you can add olives one day, another avocado, tuna...

Also quite confident you're not in anything close to mortal danger but life improves when you get leaner, a bit disgusting how much better everyone treats you.

>>18793427
Cook with it you fine gentleman/lady.

I only recently discovered this food "hack" which is actually just wisdom of the impoverished. If you are making some meat and there is fat left over, use it as a substitution the next time a recipe requires "oil" or "butter". You will have saved some money by not having to replenish your oil reserves earlier, AND the flavor profile of the meat will be transferred into whatever you use to cook it with.
You can make like a fried zucchini by just putting (any veg really) directly into the meat fat after removing the meat from the still hot pan.
Add some wine or vinegar (pref balsamic myself) and use a pan safe utensil to scrape at the meat bits in the bottom, it will help flavor the veg while also allowing you to keep the salt content of your dish lower!

(There is sodium in most meat, especially if it was pre-seasoned/marinated, so the sodium will transfer into your second dish cooked in the pan)

I am sharing this with you because I just used some sausage fat in my risotto replacing the butter I would usually use, and OHHHHY boy it's in the top 5 risottos I have ever made.

I was considering trying to cook for a living but afraid it will make me lose a hobby if I had to depend on it to live.

Hope you are well and that this is received well.
Buon' appetito!

Once it cools, it’s semi-solid like butter, except it’s infused with smoky bacon flavour. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Strain bacon fat into a sealable jar until enough is collected
Melt fat and add to boiling water, allow it to mix together
Pour into wide bowl, chill until lard sets firm
Dump water and particles, flip the cake of fat and scrape any leftover bits out
Melt fat into a crockpot or saucepot if you don't have one, put in oven at 220-240F to cook off any excess moisture
(Optionally) Strain this fat through cheesecloth or a rough coffee filter if you observe any additional particles.

Wahlah, you now have relatively pure and refined lard you can use for baking, low temp frying, or sautee. Works as a great replacement for flavoring stir fry.

Make a brine.
>Bring 2 quarts of water to a boil in a 4 quart saucepan
>1 cup of salt
>Small handful of whole black peppercorns
>5 sprigs of thyme
>10 sprigs of parsley
>1 lemon cut in half
>1/4 cup of honey, or sugar
>turn off heat add ice cubes until the saucepan is full making a total of 4 quarts of brine that is now cool enough to use
Brine over night in the fridge 12 hours max. You can re-use the brine a second time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18799449
>what do I marinade these in to be baked in the oven?
I like thighs marinated (overnight) in seasoned greek yogurt, then just move the dish the oven to bake right in the marinade. From inspiration from yogurt II recipe in Ismail Merchant's cookbook passionate meals, I cook grated ginger, grated garlic, cumin in a small saucepan til softened, remove from heat, stir in yogurt when cooled, add garam masala, zest of 1 lemon, juice of 1 lemon, and maybe juz it up a bit more with your preference of more corander, ginger, cayenne, cumin or whatever you like to balance the garam masala, maybe a bit orf cardamom or bay leaf, depending.

That greek yogurt softens the chicken so tenderly, and the garlic and ginger gets deep flavor. Double the marinade for a pourover sauce you can add to your veggies or rice side. garnish with cilantro, or green onions, of couse.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Season with salt and pepper, then bake them. Make gravy with the pan juices. Legs are the best part of the chicken so I make a roast dinner when I get legs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18799449
use yogurt or buttermilk as a base, then go in any flavor direction you like, really. I prefer dark red/brown spices like smoked paprika, chili powder, cumin, a little hit of cinnamon, but there's plenty of other options. Fennel, anise and some nice green herbs like fresh or dried oregano and basil would work just as well, but make sure to prep spices before adding by toasting them and then low-heat-infusing them into some olive oil or coconut oil for a few minutes to really let those flavors pop, then add them into the marinade base.

Hawke and Keating built a 'sin tax' in the 80's that would stay ahead of CPI inflation. When you buy a bottle of spirits you pay over $90 duties per litre of pure alcohol. Beer is over $55/litre pure IIRC but wine is just taxed at 29% of the wholesale price (because Keating is a cunt and liked to drink wine).
It's why VB about 10 years ago cut their alcohol to 4.6% to keep the price of a slab down, but had to put it back up to 4.9% because people would rather pay an extra 80c a slab for the real thing.
Boags Premium went from a crisp, full-bodied lager at 5% to a skunky watery 4.6% mess to save themselves a few million a year. Used to be one of my favourite beers, now I just drink Boags Draught instead because the price difference isn't worth it.

>>18787219
Here in beautiful Tassie we eat the local wallabies, they taste like kangaroo, only cuter.

The main issue is that our megafauna were wiped out by centuries of firestick farming before they could evolve smaller forms like in many other parts of the world. So the desertification of much of the continent meant few large herbivores. The largest native herbivore by weight IIRC is the dugong. There really wasn't much to base a cuisine on because all you really have is possums, cuscus, dugong, sea turtle, emu and various macropodiae. Seals and muttonbirds are available but severely limited in geography.

As far as edible native plants, apart from macadamias our native plants are difficult to cultivate as their yield per acre is so low. Even when supplied with plenty of water and nutrients they have evolved to fruit only grudgingly and in amounts just necessary for reproduction.

If you're interested there is an excellent book I highly recommend named "One Continuous Picnic: a gastronomic history of Australia" by Symons, which covers how we developed from a precolonial diet to the modern day full of convenience and junk foods without developing the 'peasant' or 'traditional' cuisine culture that anchors all the great cuisines of the world.

https://books.google.com.au/books/about/One_Continuous_Picnic.html?id=_N3qh4chXxwC

>which covers how we developed from a precolonial diet to the modern day full of convenience and junk foods without developing the 'peasant' or 'traditional' cuisine culture that anchors all the great cuisines of the world.
That seems like it's either tailored to the Tasmanian culture, or it's a very naïve point of view.
Millions of migrants from all those countries have shaped Australian food culture for over 100 years, moreso than most other New World nations for various reasons.
Travel through the eastern suburbs of Melbourne by train and you can still see all the backyard vineyards from the Greek and Italian migrants, all still thriving, and I presume many have been adopted by more recent arrivals, opening up even greater culinary options.
There is also the fact that Australia is one of very few nations that can domestically grow tropical and temperate produce without the loss of quality associated with importation.

>>18787373
The book discusses a failure of 'white Australia' to develop a 'traditional' cuisine (which is my point) but this is not the same as importing foreign-born persons and their cuisines (which is also covered by the book).

You also have to bear in mind that Australia was pretty much a closed shop until the 50's when Greeks, Jews and Italians were grudgingly declared culturally compatible with 'white Australia' and allowed in to help rebuild the economy after WW2.

The Tasmanian focus was because Tasmania was (and remains) an agricultural state very close in weather and seasons to Great Britain, and there were a lot of British emigres who wrote extensively about similarities between the two.

I'd encourage you to read the book, if only because it's literally the best book ever published on how Australian food and culture have interacted as society has changed.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18795874
A $1k rice cooker is not necessary, but absolutely fantastic if you love rice.

Anova precision oven is not necessary, but the size is actually really great. Bigger than a toaster oven, but a lot smaller than an oven. I use it for a lot more than my old toaster oven and my oven.

Sous vide. Meats on easy mode. If you're cooking a lotta of burgers, steaks, etc it is a god send for consistent and delicious output. Boiling in a plastic bag meme activate.

Microwave don't have an never will. The anova oven works 10000x better albeit much slower.

Air fryer. Only good if you like crispy things and eat a lot of frozen food. NOT the same as a convection oven.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18796416
The automated pressure cooking works excellently with my foodi.

I have yet to make any bread with my apo, but I can tell at 100% steam it would do good things with steamed buns. I've been doing a lot of experimenting with cooking meats.

The really fun part about the apo is that it is a very novel way to cook food, so you can really let your imagination run wild with experimentation.

For example
I set it at 185ish and 100% steam for perfectly cooked potatoes, but I used a silicon "bowl" and had the potatoes submerged in heavy cream, butter, cheese, and bacon. After maybe 2 hours I used my food mill to turn the entire thing into mashed potatoes. Superbly delicious.

48hr meats with 100% steam also works amazing.

>>18796883
The zoji you want depends on how much you love short grain rice and how much you're willing to spend. A pressure + induction cooker makes remarkably delicious short grain rice. If you eat rice 3-5 days a week getting the 500 dollar induction+pressure model will make you be a worthwhile purchase. If you cook mainly long grain getting the base 150 dollar model is more than enough for excellent rice.

The flame dance model has a "burnt bottom" setting that perfectly crisps the rice for claypot style bowls. :D Incredibly delicious.

The burnt bottom setting has gone to near blackened rice, but it has never tasted burnt. It's incredible what the Japs have done with their love of rice.

posts.com:
>>18795889
I get really upset when a person calls an immersion circulator a sous vide. Let's review...
>Immersion circulator - an instrument designed to circulate a liquid such as water while heating said liquid to a precise temperature determined by the user. Circulation of the liquid ensures consistent distribution of heat throughout its volume
>Sous vide - a method, interpreted as "under vaccuum" in French, that involves vaccuum sealing foodstuffs within plastic envelopes with the intent to cook them in a liquid bath, usually with the aid of an immersion circulator
>Water oven - an apparatus for cooking that combines an immersion circulator with a volume of water to acheive a temperature stable environment in which foods can be heated to a consistent temperature for a given length of time
When immersion circulators first came onto the scene, adventurous chefs were doing cool things with them. Now, a victim of its own success, the circulator is inseparable from sous vide cooking and "muh perfect well done steak". This isn't just autism. These words have meanings apart from each other. Vaccum sealing is useful, even without cooking via circulator (e.g. marinating meats or compressing fruit). Circulators can work their magic without plastic bags (e.g. coaxing unique textures from eggs or hot water bath for making yogurt in jars). The possibilities are vast. It's not just a steak machine.

>>18797060
The foodi is for air frying frozen food, dry beans, and when you need extended pressure cooking. You can make a super rich stock in the foodi to use in the zoji for a super flavorful claypot.

The rice cooker will always "dry" the liquid out of the pot. There is a porridge setting and water level, but that's a totally different dish. If you can get some dried scallops it makes a super delicious congee tho.

The thing I discovered is adding raw chorizo on top of your rice before cooking makes amazing rice.

>>18799768
I bought one of these scratch and dent from niggazon a few years ago for $41. It's marketed as a turkey fryer though I have never fried a turkey in it. Holds nearly 3 gallons of oil. The major issue with 95% of consumer level deep fryers is they hold a minuscule amount of oil that cannot hold any thermal mass when you toss something in. If your oil drops temp to hard that's how your food gets oily and nasty. With nearly 3 gallons of oil you can deep fry all you want and it comes out like a restaurant would. The only downside is it takes a bit to preheat. I keep mine outside on the patio so my house doesn't get that deep fryer stinky oil smell that never comes out.

posts.com: Old Fashioned learning update on posts last month: tonight I realized the importance of having adequate citrus, or at least not using shitty or old citrus in your cocktails. I'm working with Manhattans now and I was confused at why they were turning out so fucking bitter, but then realized it was a mix of either not thoroughly rinsing glasses (it's my own glass, same drink bases, so what's the big deal? the oils stay in!), having old citrus to peel (the oranges were bought on discount and have been in the fridge for over a month I think?), and reusing peels between drinks hours apart (again, it's my own drink, my own glass, and I'm experimenting on low alcohol volumes, so I figured what was the big fucking deal?). Some combination of the three -- probably the reusing of the old peels especially -- resulted in extremely bitter Manhattans. Using a fresh peel (of the same old oranges in just a rinsed glass) with a reposado tequila manhattan (Blue Nectar rep, M&R rosso, Peychaud's) had much much better results. I'm still not achieving the balance I want with these cocktails, but at least I'm finally not taking steps backwards.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18784067
5 (or possibly more) now actually. Rather than give my unresearched diatribe (and I would have to look up the specific months required for aging) I'll just link you to this article: https://www.bonappetit.com/story/types-of-tequila

If you want an all-round substitute for any type of cocktail mix, you probably want to start with a reposado. From what I've read the best intro reposado buy on all counts (accessibility, cost, etc) is probably Espolon, but with tequila there's a lot of great brands and a lot of personal taste involved. With any new liquor, look for tastings in your area and go -- even if they cost some $50 at the door, IT'S ALWAYS WORTH IT (not for wine or beer where there's a ton of free tastings however).

Adding to Bon Appetit's list, there are agave spirits in general including mezcals (of which tequila is of course a subtype), but don't dive into all this right away unless you live in Mexico or near the border and can access good bottles on the cheap. There are also non-100% agave spirits (mixtos), which should always be avoided in the U.S., but can again be fair game to explore in Mexico.

Unaged is cheaper, extra aged is more expensive, just like with any other liquor. Unaged can be just as good to sip as extra aged, just like any other liquor. Do some background research on general reviews from people in the know (liquor.com has nice intro best-of lists), but don't read more than you drink, just like any other liquor.

5. Poor education surrounding nutrition, nobody reads or understands nutrition labels, most can’t be bothered to track calories

>>18794099

My weight fluctuated between 85kg and 125kg (187-275 freedom kee's).

I can tell you up to 95kg working out, running, fitting normal clothes are all fine. Up to 105kg you have to start accomodating for extra fat (buy larger sizes), you feel your legs bumping into your stomach when cycling. From 115kg and on, it starts to get hard to even run, because your breathing isn't under control, and your knees/ankles start to hurt and suffer.

So I would say, being 110% of your weight at a 12-15% fat percentage wouldn't give you that many problems, and your actual nutrition would impact you more. Anything above 130% of your healthy weight starts impacting your life significantly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18798113
I use to work at a Five Guy's, they're good but you could easily cook what we made at home cheaper. My biggest gripe is the foil traps any moisture inside, turning it into a messy fuck up if you don't free it within minutes. The good times was getting on lunch break and destroying a 1/2 lb. burger in 7 minutes then sleeping the rest. The milkshakes are awful, our machine would struggle to pump as soon as the slurry would reach peak thickness; get them anywhere else. Excluding the coldbrew, get dry ingredients only. The hot dogs are an honest to goodness ripoff we had no business selling, buy them anywhere else. The fries are the best I’ve had when cooked right, turned me into a fry Nazi for a while. If you overcooked them orange any soft cooked fry could beat them. There’s no MK Ultra secret, completely remove all the starch (rinse the ever-living shit out of them until the water basin stays clear). Its how fries use to be made and honestly I still think most other restaurant fries are shit enough to make me choose any other side dish. Like the burgers though they got weird when allowed to stay too moist for long. I have no regrets working there but nowdays most anyone here could out do them for far cheaper.

>>18800636
Ima hook you up fampai.

Take rice, put in rice cooker 1 part rice to 1.5 roughly parts water. I usually put in half a cup of rice and 3/4ths a cup of water (feeds about 2 people).

Put in a bit of salt, probably about half a teaspoon. Put in some Garlic powder (eyeball it).

Stir it up a bit.

Put in a whole roma tomato.

Chop up some veggies (or just toss some frozen veggies in there) (your choice on what veggies).

Add some kind of pre-cooked meat. I usually toss potstickers or some meat that I cooked from the previous night.

Turn on rice cooker.

Come back when it's done and eat.

Have fun

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18788555
>you need to know all the tips and tricks
Being a good cook isn't about tips or tricks.
It's about being able to eyeball seasonings, knowing what goes with what, timing, surface to volume ratios, salt vs moisture levels, getting the right equipment, knowing the taste of those you're cooking for, etc.

You can go download a million meatloaf recipes, and you might even like most of them, but only practice will let you riff something up with what you have on hand.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18788555
First take a good meat. Pork/beef combination or just beef. Around 30% of fat content total. It should be really cold.
Grind it. Cool it down again because grinder will heat it up. Mix it really, really well and never allow its temperature rise higher than +11 Celsius. You can add 10% of meat weight of icy cold water if you want. Takes around 5 minutes of mixing. You'll know it's mixed well when it almost doesn't stick to the bowl anymore and stays in one piece. When you move your fingers apart you'll see long strings of mince. Add salt, around 1-2% of meat weight (depends on your taste really). Sometimes it just doesn't mix like that which means either temperature was fucked up or meat wasn't aged at least for 3-4 days or started to rot.
Put it in your baking form. Set temperature in the oven around 90 Celsius. Add few trays with water into the oven to raise humidity. Put thermometer into the center of the loaf and bake until 70 celsius reached. Cool it down. Enjoy.

We'd get into screaming arguments constantly about how lazy and worthless she was. I felt like an asshole for it, but goddamn she was a real piece of work. The only reason I dealt with all this was for the kids, and also because the sex is great.

But one night, I got fed up. Not only did she get drunk, neglect the kids, and made me top Ramen for dinner, but she decided to give me attitude too. She was being real fucking bitchy. So I told my grandparents to keep an eye on the kids and told my wife we were going to go out and have dinner together. I drove maybe 3 blocks to a quiet area (we live in Oregon, it's not hard to find a quiet field) and I got out of the car, went around like I was going to open her door for her and let her out, and I just beat the shit out of her while she was still seatbelted. After a few punches, I asked her if she wanted to go back to her parents. She started screaming and yelling and said yes, so I beat the shit out of her again. Then I asked her what she wanted to do. She finally got smart and said she wanted to go home. So I took her home and dared her to start trouble. I even handed her my cellphone and dialed her mom's number on the drive home. I made her talk to her mom, while daring her to fucking say something.

Before that incident, I had never laid a hand on her. But I had always threatened it. I told her "one of these days, if you don't straighten up, I'm going to lay hands on you."

All my meals have been on time, and she just recently tried to make a meatloaf. It was mediocre, but I was just thrilled that she tried.
Do with this information what you will.

posts.com:
The key is a good seasoning and making Bouletten instead. My recipe:
500 g half pork half beef mince
3 slices of sandwich bread thrown in a blender
1 large egg
1 finely diced medium or large onion
14 g salt
2 g black pepper
1 g white pepper
1 g mace
1 g ginger
0.5 g cardamom
0.5 g allspice
0.3 g coriander
2 g paprika
A handfull chopped parsley
Maybe also a garlic clove

Just knead everything together until it binds well, turn it into 100 g balls and fry them in clarified butter or oil.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18786805
I love meatloaf, and when I make them, there are never leftovers. It is easy to make a meatloaf that never set, bland or even both. First mistake is baking the meatloaf in the loaf pan, it sits in its grease and is essentially poached, that would not be appetizing and almost guaranteed to fall apart. Use the loaf pan to make the shape only, lining it with suran wrap, then placing the meat mixture in the pan, pulling the loaf out by the suran wrap. roll it onto a parchment paper lined baking sheet. Many people overcook their meatloaf. If you are only making a one pound (even a two pound loaf) and cooked it for an hour, you dried it out. Many dont leave it set for 10 minutes before slicing it, probably the most common mistake. You cut it too soon, it will be a crumbled mess. As far as amping up the flavor, crushed seasoned croutons are my go to (avoid oatmeal and cracker crumbs, that will zap the flavor out of it). Milk as a liquid in the meatloaf sounds awful, use beer or a half and half mixture of beef broth and red wine. Thyme and parsley with a good amount of salt and pepper is the only seasoning you'll need.

>>18800161
I used to be quite fat. The potato diet as mentioned is solid, but it's not reliant on potatoes at all. Ray Cronise, who originated it only picked potatoes because he knew Penn Jillette liked them. But anything simple, like rice and beans or virtually anything bland will suffice. The goal is to reset taste buds so you're not eating for pleasure, you are eating for survival. It doesn't really matter because it's not meant to be a long term diet. The point is to change your relationship to the food you eat.

That said, I went with what to this day I call the Stalone method. I reme as a fat kid watching some old talk show where they asked him how he was always in such good shape.

He said its easy, if you eat well and exercise 5 days a week, when it comes to the weekend you can do whatever. "Pizza, hamburgers, ice cream... doesn't matter. You've done good it's covered" pretty similar to how the rock now talks about cheat days. It really works though.

And here's a thing, I used to drink Coke like crazy, but on that cut it out other than weekends. The first week was awful and coke on Saturday felt like an amazing relief. The second week it was tasty but I didn't crave it like I one did. The third week I drank it mostly just cause I could. By week 4 I did bother, it seemed gross.

Now I have it on rare occasion and it's an intense treat but that's it.

You have to work with your will power and habits first, anon. No diet trick is going to help because you're trying to build a house by starting from the roof instead of the ground.
I'm not going to send you to the gym or jogg, because this starts with the mind. Set yourself some goals you can achieve. Make your bed everyday when you wake up, even if its annoying. Wash your dishes immediately after eating. Clean that room/garage/backyard that you have been postponing for ages. Sell that extra thing you keep saving in your closet/attic/basement.
Try to get involved with community work, find a new hobbie, try to meet people in events and such.
Good habits work like chain, once you get one the next will follow. If you look forward to do something then you'll want to be at your best, to show your friends and people you care about that you're still made of good stuff, just like them.
Once you finish what you start, and once you get the will to do things that you don't want to do, but you still accomplish them, then you'll have the solid ground to face this with bigger weapons.

Still, it's not only about what you cook. You must understand your metabolism. You are obviously insulin resistant, and yout gut microbiome is also fucked up.
You have to eat more protein and fiber, foods that will saciate you. You say that you always want another dish right? It's not the same to eat a second plate of steak than a second plate of spaghetti. Eat things thats require a lot of chewing, get your jaw exhausted so your hunger becomes something secondary. There is tricks to fill your belly too. Drink a big glass of water before meals. Have some collagen peptide supplements to entertain your stomach with it before meals, it has zero calories and it's healthy. You don't need to starve yourself at the start, you can eat as always and then choose a time (6 pm) to stop eating until next morning. Half fasts are good for this, it will help you control your cravings.

Not necessarily. You can be a huge foodie and not gain weight because you're not eating like shit. I eat varied, healthy foods at gargantuan quantities. But I avoid carefully any form of food that would get me bloated like a balloon.
A gallon of clam chowder is roughly 2300 kcal, meaning he can drink an entire gallon of that shit throughout the day and not GAIN weight. you can eat 10 kgs of kimchi to get the same goal, or 1.5kg of cooked paella (which is basically flavored rice and protein), and i guarantee you that many classic dishes, especially the ones with green veggies, can be eaten by the kilograms and you'd still get away with it.

On the other hand, eat a bag of chips and a tub of ben and jerry ice cream : 2300kcal. Except I know a fuck ton of people, thin people included, that will eat that shit throughout the day (not as a habit of course) and still have a lunch and a dinner. And that's exactly what fat people (including me when I was one) do. They eat extremely calorie dense foods that aren't satiating you because your brain sucks at counting modern food calories because the amount of calories per gram just doesn't make sense to it. We got shit that tastes like bananas but have 100 times the fat, but our brains didn't evolve fast enough to compute that.

I remember my dad being a fat fuck too, eating hamburgers and ice cream and shit but shaming me because I once drank a an entire 1liter carton of soup, because to him, the calories didn't matter, but the volumes did. But now i eat gargantuan meals and still lost 40kgs. And no rebound too, because going back to a baseline, no weight loss amount of calories translated into eating way too much food for me to relapse.

>>18800161
mix cooked white rice with a little coconut oil (just for texture, not for flavor) with some light spices like some dried garlic and pepper. Have that as your baseline filler food because it's pretty easy to add things to it to make you not hate it, like a little cream or some mushrooms.

But if you really need to lose weight, do what i've been doing: pick a day, and do one situp, one pushup, and one pullup. Then, the next day, do one more. Don't ever take a day off. It's only ever one more than the day before, so it's never too much to ask, and eventually it becomes a habit that you don't want to break. You'll get to the point of where your regular muscle you normally have will finally be tested (for me it was around ten days) and you'll want to stop, but it'll be a hundred times easier to keep going because instead of jumping right in to a large number, you had a slow, methodical increase which means your cardio will never be too overtaxed.
Remember: the key to change that sticks is not dramatic changes, it's small, easily-maintainable alterations that can synergize. Don't fad diet and only fad diet, do a little diet, a little exercise, and a little habit alteration, then when those become normal, do a little more.

>>18800161
Don’t drink your calories. Soda and fruit juice will not satisfy your need for food and provide little nutritional benefit. Be wary about how much oil you use, even 1 tablespoon of olive oil has a lot of calories. Salad dressings and some sandwich spreads are also a common trap when it comes to this, adding too much sugar or cream to coffee can be this too.

Replace unhealthy food you eat with a healthier alternative. If you have a sweet tooth, eat fruit instead of chocolate. If you like to snack, think of a healthier snack to munch on. Fruits and vegetables are good for this because they’re light on calories. Unsalted nuts are decent too so long as you pay attention to portion sizes. Honey may seem “healthier” but it really isn’t that much better. Consider baking food you may normally fry since you won’t need to use as much oil. Breakfasts are some of the least healthy foods people often eat, many of them are like desserts

Eat food with a lot of fiber, because that will fill you up more. Fruits, vegetables, whole grains are all good for this.

Drink plenty of water

Minimize eating out, be very careful about prepackaged meals. When you eat food prepared by someone else you have no control over the ingredients being used. A lot of food in restaurants or prepackaged foods are designed by a profit-seeking business to be tasty to increase demand, not necessarily to be healthy

Eat slowly

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
If you're 450 lb you can lose a lot of weight without trying too hard with your diet.

The most important thing is the quantity of what you eat. The first step is to train the stomach to accept less food and shrink to a smaller size. What worked for me in the past is to do 16 hour fasts and only eat within an 8 hour window in the day. So only eat at lunch, then dinner at 6, maybe a snack at 7:45 if you want. And since you're 470lb, you can eat big portions and still lose weight. You still have to give up binging on fast food if you're doing that, your meal will have to be actually healthy foods.

The simplest go-to is protein (chicken, pork, beef that you've cooked) and vegetables (broccoli, asparagus, etc). But you can eat as big a portion as you want since you're 470lb, you'll lose a ton of weight within a couple of months. For snacks just eat more protein, maybe cured meats like salami and jerkey, cheese. Just don't eat potato chips or anything sweet. A 470lber needs to cut out starches and sugars to start building back insulin function, and it will keep you less hungry. No need to go full keto though, like you can have something like mashed potato within reason (not every day).

If you follow this for just a few days, you'll find that it becomes easy after maybe 4-5 days as your stomach shrinks. Only the first 2-3 days are hard, it's literally effortless from there.
This is a cheat/cope type of weight loss, but it's a very good place to start. After you gain momentum, you can try looking more seriously into your diet and look into exercising.

>>18800584
Crushed red pepper hack:
>put some pepper flakes in a jar
>add just enough rice vinegar to re-hydrate the flakes but not make it soupy
>mince, or crush a small clove of garlic with a pinch of salt until nearly a paste
>add the garlic and just enough olive oil to cover the pepper flakes
>mix the ingredients with a fork until the garlic emulsifies the oil and flakes into a thick paste
>store in fridge and use on noodles, rice, etc.

posts.com: My favorite pasta sauce to make at home is a simple Marinara sauce. This sauce is easy to make and requires only a few ingredients. To make this sauce, you will need olive oil, garlic, canned tomatoes, dried oregano, dried basil, salt, and pepper. First, heat the olive oil in a large pot over medium-high heat. Once the oil is hot, add the garlic and saute until fragrant. Then, add the canned tomatoes and the dried herbs. Simmer the sauce for about 15-20 minutes, or until it has thickened. Finally, season with salt and pepper to taste, and enjoy!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: My Favorite pasta sauce to make at home is a creamy garlic Alfredo sauce. This sauce is smooth and flavorful, with a hint of garlic. To make this sauce, you will need butter, heavy cream, garlic, Parmesan cheese, salt, pepper, and parsley. Begin by melting the butter in a large pot over medium heat. Once the butter is melted, add the garlic and saute until fragrant. Then, add the cream and Parmesan cheese to the pot and stir until the cheese is melted. Simmer the sauce on low heat for about 10 minutes, or until it has thickened. Lastly, season with salt and pepper to taste, and sprinkle with fresh parsley before serving.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: My favorite pasta sauce to make at home is a rustic Bolognese sauce. This rich and flavorful sauce is perfect for your favorite pasta dish, and requires just a few ingredients. To make Bolognese sauce, you will need olive oil, ground beef, garlic, onion, carrots, celery, canned tomatoes, tomato paste, dried oregano, red wine vinegar, bay leaves and sugar. Begin by heating the olive oil in a large pot over medium-high heat until shimmering. Then add the ground beef to the pot and sauté until browned. Next add the garlic, onion, carrots and celery to the pot and cook until softened. Finally stir in the remaining ingredients along with salt and pepper to taste. Reduce heat to low and simmer for at least an hour before serving over your favorite pasta dish!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: My favorite pasta sauce to make at home is a creamy roasted red pepper sauce. This robust and flavorful sauce requires simple ingredients, including olive oil, garlic, cream cheese, roasted red peppers, white wine vinegar and dried basil. To make this sauce, start by heating the olive oil in a pot over medium-high heat. Once the oil is hot, add the garlic and sauté until fragrant. Then add the cream cheese and mix it until melted. Add the roasted red peppers to the pot and stir until combine with the other ingredients. Finally, season with white wine vinegar and dried basil before lowering heat to low for about 15 minutes or until heated through. Serve over your favorite pasta dish for an irresistibly delicious main course!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: My favorite pasta sauce to make at home is an herby puttanesca sauce. This classic Italian sauce features olives, capers, anchovies and herbs for a bold and flavorful finish that you’ll absolutely love. To make this delicious dish, start by heating the olive oil in a large pot over medium-high heat. Once hot, add the garlic and anchovies and sauté until fragrant. Then stir in the tomato paste, followed by the canned tomatoes with their juices as well as the capers and olives. Finally season with fresh parsley, oregano, basil, salt and pepper before simmering on low heat for about 15 minutes or until desired consistency is achieved. Serve warm over your favorite cooked pasta!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: My favorite pasta sauce to make at home is a simple basil pesto. This bright and flavorful sauce requires only a few ingredients, such as olive oil, garlic, fresh basil leaves, Parmesan cheese and pine nuts. To make this sauce, start by bringing the olive oil to a simmer in a small pot over medium-high heat. Once the oil is hot, add the garlic and sauté until fragrant. Then add the basil leaves and pine nuts to the pot and cook for about 2 minutes. Finally, remove from heat and stir in Parmesan cheese before transferring to a food processor or blender. Blend until smooth before serving over your favorite pasta dish!

Think of the rabbi as the religious equivalent of H&S/L&I agents. They inspect the production for anything that doesn't follow the rules which govern kashrut and, if it all checks out, the declaration is made that the resulting product is kosher.
Different branches of Judaism have different standards of what is and is not kosher, so one factory may have a few different rabbis inspect. One might say production is kosher for his specific sect of Yid, but another will say that it doesn't meat her sect's kosher rules.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18799409
I mix it with softened cream cheese, chives and a little "crab salt" (idk wtf it's made of, but it's good af) as a sandwich spread. It's also nice as a filling for cannelloni or large pasta shells, especially if you swap the cream cheese for ricotta. If made this way, I like a chunky tomato sauce, for it. Just garlic, olive oil, hand-crushed tomatoes, tomato juice and more sweet parsley than you think you'd need. Arrange the cooked-and-stuffed cannelloni in a baking dish, top with the freshly made sauce and bake to heat through.

There's also the obvious options of crabcakes, crab salad and crab chowder.

I've only used the gigantic tins that are sold in the refrigerated seafood section of most supermarkets for any of these dishes so if you're using shelf stable tinned crab, YMMV.

>>18789591
>>18789601
IMO beans matter most, then burrs/grinder and water, then recipe. Also the tasting notes are generally impressions of what the taster was reminded of vs what they directly tasted.

Assuming good beans, water that doesnt suck, and good burrs grinder, you'll have to fix your grind size, and/or water temp and/or pouring technique.

I've been using Hoffmann's 1 Cup v60 method with 50GH/15KH water with the following tweaks for my burrs depending on beans and getting tasting notes very similar to what the roasters listed:

Too acidic / weak = grind finer, increase temp

Too bitter / flavors muddled & undiscernible = grind coarser, agitate less (no swirl / stir / pour closer to coffee bed), lower temp

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18798464
Brush the retained grounds off the outside of the burrs after every use then blow the chaff dust out of the barrel either with your lungs or a air puffer bulb thinger. Fine dust and coffee oils accumulate after several months. You do not need to do this often, but this is when you break it down and clean it with dry paper towels and cotton swabs. Don't use water. Take as little apart as you need to to get in the nooks and crannies. Some grinders are easy to partly or fully reassemble. Other ones are a pain in the ass to put back together because they require resetting the burr sets. Never detach the cone burr from the shaft. Never remove the burr ring from its retainer. There are videos of people breaking down every grinder.

Id make soup.

Boil the chicken in water with some chicken boullion cubes, thyme, rosemary, bayleefs, for about 1.5 hours

Take the whole chicken out and put in the fridge for an hour to cool/harden it and make it easier to debone.

Strain your broth of the thyme, rosemary, bayleefs.

Add your desired veggies ( I use corn, carrots, peas, lima beans. Can usually get a frozen bag of veggies for cheap) and a small can of tomato paste. Season how you want. I usually use s+p, majoram, onion salt, parsley. Add a little diced garlic. If you dont have enough broth, you can add some chicken stock. Simmer for 30 min.

Debone chicken. Save the bones if you want. Shred/cut chicken into chuncks. Add to pot.

Simmer for 30 min. Add dumplings if you want.

Theres your meal prep for the week. If you dont add dumplings you can freeze the soup and its good for about 3 months.

>Chicken in covered pot

>If you can easily separate the meat from the bones, the chicken is done
From there:
>Remove chicken for processing
>(Optional) skim any excess fat from the top
>(Optional) strain the juices for a clearer soup
>Throw into the juices the cabbage, other veggies, chicken meat, whatever you want in your soup
>(Optional) If you want a thicker soup, use the chicken fat to make a roux and add it back to the soup
>Simmer until the veggies are soft, add liquids as needed
>Taste and season as needed, it will probably need some more salt and herbs

If you roast it with the breast-side up, you can uncover the pot and broil it for a few minutes to crisp the skin and use the crispy skin and breast for other meals while using the rest of the meat for the soup :3

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
cut it into squares.
You want to get the water out of it so it can be cooked without being a weird soggy mess. Best way to do this is actually to boil it in salted water like pasta for 5-10m and then lay out to dry completely ideally. Pressing it is a meme, no restaurant on the planet does that because it's stupid.
Now that it's dry toss it in a mixture of corn starch with equal part flour and salt / pepper. You could probably add other seasonings if you want. Now you can either fry it or bake it. I usually bake it because then I can walk away and come back later. If frying use a good amount of oil. More than you would think probably, but not deep fry. You want the oil to come up the squares a bit. Get all sides light brown and ur done.
If baking I also put in slightly smaller squares of sweet potato tossed in cornstarch as well. This is the secret to getting that crispy outside edge on sweet potatoes. Toss the tofu and sweet potatoes in some oil and bake 400F until brown enough for you. For me that's about 20 minutes and I give it a good stir after about 15m.
One of my weekly meals is baked tofu and sweet potatoes like this with a basic peanut sauce on rice. Btw for an oil I like coconut oil for this but if you do that you'd have to melt the oil before you toss everything in oil. For me that's easy because I'm using a cast iron to bake it all in anyway so I just melt the oil in that. Go ahead and use your sneed oil here if that's your thing.

Another one: dip in egg, then fry, then add light soy sauce at the end.
Also you can put it in meat stew.
Another thing is there are many types of tofu. If you go to a Chinese supermarket you can get a few other varieties for frying:
Qianzhang 千张 - a thin yellow sheet. Cut into thin strips, fry with julienned leak pork and veg (parboiled celery especially). This type of tofu is also very high in protein. 30g per 100g. Like meat.
Pic related - xianggan 香干 (has other names too): flat 1cm thick slabs of firm tofu that look like they've been marinated. They are just basically a firm version of tofu and hold up well to a vigorous fry. They can be cut into thin strips and fried/braised with meat.

>>18803836
alright here's a really loose recipe
i typically use firm tofu. no silken
break block apart with hands, lightly squeeze to get some of the water out
cook chopped onion + garlic in pan until soft. add your veggies (red bell pepper, tomatoes, zucchini, etc. or mushrooms) and cook a couple more minutes
add in your broken-up tofu and seasonings, making sure everything gets incorporated evenly. i typically use turmeric for color, curry powder, paprika, black or white pepper, nutritional yeast, and sometimes dried tarragon. harissa is a god-tier add-in if you have it. some people also add black salt to give it an eggy flavor but that's not my thing. basically whatever you'd eat normally with scrambled eggs or a frittata. can be easily adjusted to fit other flavor profiles
make sure to taste semi-often, as the flavor will become more concentrated as water leaves the tofu. be careful not to cook too long, otherwise the tofu will lose its bouncy, egg-like texture
near the end i add baby spinach and sometimes cheese. when those things are wilted/melted it's done
pair with your fav hot sauce and home fries, eat on toast, or make breakfast burritos. bacon (or its vegetarian equivalent) pairs really well with this

Pale ale =/= IPA
Pale ales are usually fairly hoppy, but the hops are added during the boiling process of brewing. IPA's generally have more hops than a regular pale ale added during the boil, as well as even more hops added after fermentation has slowed down which is called "dry-hopping."

Good morning /ck/! Today I'm going to teach you how to make delicious southern hoe cakes. For those that don't know, hoe cakes or johnny cakes are essentially cornbread in pancake form. They're less dense and not as dry as traditional cornbread, and in my opinion they're tastier too! I'll show you every little step so you don't miss anything in case you want to try my recipe. Also, forgive my kitchen, as I live in a ghetto Mexican neighborhood and they think this shit is fine to rent out because they have no standards. Hopefully when I move away in spring, my next kitchen will be nicer so my pictures don't look so shitty.

Hope you enjoy learning to make hoe cakes! Let's do this!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Here are all the ingredients you'll need. It's a rather simple recipe, which I'll post after this image since I wrote it down to put on the fridge. Essentially it's half self-rising flour and half cornmeal, with a few other ingredients to make the hoe cakes fluffy and soft.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: And here's my recipe.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Okay! First thing's first, I'm actually out of oil right now (the oil can be your personal preference, I use peanut oil or olive oil) so I'm going to melt 1/4 a cup of butter in 1/2 cup of water. I just microwave it for about a minute and mix it up until the butter is fully dissolved, then I let it cool for a bit so it isn't hot when I add all the ingredients together.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Next, we add the rest of our wet ingredients. Two eggs and 3/4 a cup of buttermilk. You can actually make your own buttermilk by simply adding one tablespoon of vinegar into regular milk, stirring it up, and letting it sit for a few minutes. That's what I did here.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Now I've got my wet ingredients ready, so I put my dry ingredients together. There's no set amount of cajun spice I throw into the batter; I just eyeball it. Feel free to experiment with spices you personally like. You can also add in shredded cheddar or chopped jalapeno at this step too if you'd like, cheddar jalapeno hoe cakes are also fucking good.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: And now it's mixed! At this point, the batter can be as thick or thin as you personally prefer. I like a thicker batter, but if I wanted it a bit thinner I would just add a splash of milk at this step.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: In they go! I like using a cast iron pan for cooking my hoe cakes, biscuits, and pancakes. I usually like to cook them in a small bit of lard, but I'm currently out of lard so I'm just using a small amount of butter instead.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Flip! You can use pancake rules with hoe cakes, when you see bubbles on top they're ready to flip.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: For reference, this is the amount of butter I use to cook three cakes. I've noted how much I use total to count the calories for each cake, and it ends up being almost one tablespoon of butter exactly by the end of cooking.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Alrighty, now all that's left to do is finish cooking the rest of the hoe cakes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Well, three of them already got eaten by the kids. Might be about two batches of batter left. When I get them all cooked, I'll count up the calories for all the fatties and /fit/ nerds out there.

posts.com: Slicing a block of extra sharp cheddar while I wait for the rest of the cakes to cook. Got some summer sausages on sale and I need some cheese and crackers to munch with them.

They're a big hit in my household, and you can also store leftover cakes in the fridge and eat them whenever. I recommend reheating them in the toaster oven, but the microwave will do if you don't have a lot of time. I'll post calorie information shortly.

>>18787797
How stupid and thoughtless of you to ask such mundane questions the lowest of slime could answer with their own meager intellect.

A great rice cooker makes rice better, more consistently, and more conveniently than cooking it in a pot ever could.

Here is my recipe for perfect rice. It is the best, most detailed recipe for cooking the best rice in a pot on the stove. Period.

1. Weigh rice on scale note weight.
2. Rinse rice with copious amounts of room temp to cold water until water runs semi clear to clear. The more the better
3. Place rice in bowl and cover with 2-3 inches of filtered water. Wait 30 minutes or until rice appears opaque and crumbles easily when pressed between fingers.
4. Drain rice by placing in a strainer and let stand in strainer for 25 minutes.
5. Place equal parts rice and filtered water in a high walled pot. Cover rice.
6. Put heat on max temp and start a timer.
7. Once steam starts coming out of pot or water starts boiling turn heat to 2-3 or very low and cook for how long it took to reach boil.
8. Once time is up turn off heat and let sit for 15 minutes without touching.
9. Fluff rice with plastic or wooden rice scoop. Serve.

My high end rice cooker does a better job than that recipe does in less time and no fiddle fucking around. My cheaper rice cooker did not do a better job than my pot recipe.

>>18788148
It probably does. I honestly haven't spent the time testing it on lower grade rice.

My advice would be to watch the soak time carefully. It may only need 10-15 minutes. The breaking/crumble test should still apply.

You also don't need to wash medium/long grain rice as much for very high quality results. It's extremely important for short grain because it makes each grain of rice feel smooth as you chew it. Long grain rice naturally has a rougher texture to it.

I've shared my recipe quite a few times on here, but haven't heard anyone report back with results. I'd appreciate the effort.

You wash short grain because it improves the texture of the rice granules. When you wash/polish the rice it has a satisfying smooth feeling. Unwashed has a rough texture that is not as nice imo.

Travis B
write a post regarding the pros and cons of rice cookers
Pros of Rice Cookers:
-They make cooking rice easy and convenient
-They can keep rice warm for hours without burning or drying it out
-They can cook different types of rice (e.g. white, brown, sushi) to perfection
-They can also be used to cook other grains such as quinoa and barley
-Many models come with a steamer basket, which allows you to steam vegetables or seafood while the rice cooks

Cons of Rice Cookers:
-They can be expensive, especially high-end models
-They can take up a lot of counter space
-They can be difficult to clean
-Some models have a learning curve and may require some experimentation to get the perfect rice
-They can be bulky, so not suitable for small kitchen or for people who travel frequently.

Overall, rice cookers can be a great investment for anyone who cooks rice frequently or wants a convenient way to make perfect rice every time. However, they may not be the best choice for those with limited space or a tight budget.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18802850
The fan in a convection oven will only circulate air around the oven to make the temp more even, which is not what the fan in an air fryer is doing. Air has nowhere close to the heat transfer of even a basic pan, so air fryers compensate by forcing air into contact with food, imitating the process of frying. To make a chicken breast crispy you need to cook it quicker than moisture can release from it; it needs the surface to get hot in seconds, which won't happen in an oven unless you're treating it like a homemade pizza and pre-heating a heavy oven dish for the chicken to go in, or using a grill/broiler.

Pat the meat dry also, even if you're coating it in something. Use a little oil to make any dry coating stick to it, because water will just stop it crisping and turning to steam will push the coating off.

>>18802006
My favourite thing to cook innawoods is a beef stew. I bring a couple carrots, potatoes, mushrooms, an onion, tallow, and cubed beef. Throw it all in a pot, add water, and let it simmer away for a few hours. This obviously doesn't work if you're going to be hiking a lot since it's a heavy meal to be hauling around, but if you're car camping, canoeing, or just doing a short hike to your camp site, it's definitely doable and sure beats any processed dehydrated goyslop meal on the market.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18802006
Depends a lot on the kind of camping you're doing.
When I go camping I also go walking all damn day so I want to reduce weight as much as I can. I plan for a campsite near a water supply so I don't have to haul a lot of water and that gives me the option of bringing dried foods along.
Breakfast is always oats with dried fruits for sweetening. Raisins, apricots, appleslices etc.
Dinner is usually some sort of one-pot meal with rice and vegetables and any meat/fish I manage to harvest on the trip. I'll usually carry a cured sausage just in case I don't bag anything. Some lentils or beans work nicely with the rice as well. Just make sure you cook them long enough.
Chopped up chorizo or whatever works nicely in a stew.
Some game I prefer roasted on a spit instead of stewed. I know rabbit stew is popular but I prefer them roasted over a fire with the rice and veggies on the side.
If it's a short trip, say a weekend, I might also bring some bread dough along and make flatbread on rocks or wrap it around sticks and bake it over the fire. You will want to get a pretty good understanding of your dough before you try this so it doesn't expand too much and fuck up all your dry clothes in the backpack or something.


If you're near the sea you can use water from there for salting. I have one of those 35mm. film plastic canisters with a pretty basic mix of spices in it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18802043
Also on the more simple side of things, kraft dinner/mac and cheese. You can add dehydrated ground beef (or any ground meat) for your protein and bring powdered milk and a bit of salted butter. This is an option I use for longer trips when I can't preserve raw meat for multiple days at a time and need to pack on the lighter side.
